unsloth/Qwen3-14B-GGUF/Qwen3-14B-F16.ggu: A great battle was fought for Ulster at the Slieve Foy, and there were many deaths and a great assembly, namely, between Conall and Coincullan and Loegaire. 'I will strike you,' said Conall, 'the head of Messgegra who was slain before us in that assembly, each one of whom had placed a price on the heads of young warriors, and they had given them weapons and shields, and they had made them wear red cloaks over their shoulders.' And then there were notices put up in the assemblies or in the meetings which were given to them so that they would not strike with their hands

A great battle was fought for Ulster by the men of Sliab Fúait. They made a great slaughter and a rout, namely, between Conall and Coincualaind and Lóegaire. 'I will strike you,' said Conall, 'the head of Messgegra who was slain before them in the battle.' It was the custom of the Ulstermen in that assembly that each man gave a portion of his own wealth to the men of the household, and they would give them a share of their cattle and goods, so that they might make a red (i.e., bloody) slaughter upon them. And then they made a notice in the slaughter or in the rout, giving them the right of the hand

A great battle was fought for Ulster in the Slieve Foy, and there were many slain and a great rout, namely, between Conall and Coincullan and Loegaire. 'I will strike you,' said Conall, 'the head of Messgegra who was killed before them in the rout.' It was a custom of the Ulstermen in that battle that every man should take a share in the killing of a young warrior whose head and arms were carried to the king with a tribute of blood upon them. And also then there was a notice in the slaughter or rout that they would give them the hands

A great slaughter was made for Ulster by the men of Sliab Fúait. They pursued them and slew many, and a battle occurred, namely between Conall and Coinculaind and Lóegaire. 'I will strike you,' said Conall, 'the head of Messgegra who was killed before us in that battle; each Ulsterman in that battle had placed a price on the head of every young man who had not yet taken a wife or received a portion of land or cattle, and they gave them a red-garbed cloak upon their shoulders.' And then there was a notice in the slaughter or the battles given to them so that they would know by the marks of the hands
Well done, Conall,' said Conchobor, 'you have not failed to take the news of the battle from the wounded, you have not failed to bring word from them.' 'It is true,' said Conall
Good, Conall,' said Conchobor, 'either you have not heard of the news or you are not aware of the matter; you are not speaking truly.' 'It is true,' said Conall

Well done, Conall,' said Conchobur, 'you have not failed to give your advice on the matter of the information concerning the galloping horses, you have given good advice from the beginning.' 'It is true,' said Conall
Well done, Conall,' said Congobor, 'you have not neglected the inquiry into the matter of the information [given] to the men, you have not failed in your inquiry here.' 'It is true,' said Conall

They were driven back from the ford before they could reach the hill of the king. Each of them went to his own house, and he was not seen again. They brought with them Cet mac Matach to the court of Ulster. He was a man of great strength in Hérinn. It was said that he had the strength of the Fúait and three hundred men with him against the Ulaid

They brought her afterwards from the east to the west where she was born. They carried each of her two arms upon a shield. They gave to Cet, son of Matach, a chariot and a company to Ulster. The beast was in the north of Samhred in Cét. It was given to him by the king of the Fomorians with three hundred warriors along with his Ulstermen

They were brought back from the west by force before they had reached the degree of wisdom. They went each to their own dwelling place with a great crowd. They were led by Cet mac Matach to the territory beyond Ulto. The beast was in the land of Hérinn called Cet. It was driven away from the sight of the Fúait and three hundred men with him towards the Ultaib

She was carried after that by the foreigners before her body was buried. He went with a third of his army to the place where the battle was fought. The slaughter was great in Ulster, and Cet mac Matach was killed there. It was said that he was brought from the east of Hérinn to Cét. He was carried by them for three days to the men of Ulster

Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib

Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib

Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib

Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib

Cet was slain on the day when the women were in mourning. Cet was killed by Mesgegra in the house, and Conall was wounded with a spear through his head and through his shoulder, so that it passed through his body. The Ulaid came upon him and cut off his head from Cet. The ford of Átha Daire Dá Báeth is there where Conall fell. His wife was in mourning for him, and she mourned over his head and over his feet

Cet was killed on the day when the women were in mourning. Cet was slain by Mesgegra in the house, and Conall was wounded with a spear through his two sides and through his head, so that it passed through his body. The Ulaid came upon him and cut off his head from Cet. The ford of Átha Daire Dá Báeth is there where Conall fell. His wife was in mourning for him, and she mourned over his head and over his feet

Cét was killed on the day when the women were in mourning. Cét was slain by Mesgegra in the house, and Conall was wounded with a spear while his two brothers were in the house and he was at the head, so that it happened before them. The Ulaid came upon him and brought him from Cét. For the battle of Átha Daire Dá Báeth was there and the slaughter of Conall. His wife was in mourning and lamentation over his head and over his feet

Cét was killed on the day when the women were assembled in the plain. Cét was slain in the battle of Mesgegra in the plain, and Conall was wounded with a spear in his head and with a wound in his thigh, so that he fell on his face. The Ulaid gave him the burial which was due to him from Cét. The ford of Átha Daire Dá Báeth is there where Conall fell. He has his grave in the burial place, and a stone upon his head and a stone upon his foot

It was said of Crích Ross, in Sciaig Aird na Con. The Ulaid were divided into two parts at Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'My word is this!' said Conall. 'The king of the Ulaid has not given me a share of his people.' 'Not so,' said Cend Berraide, to his servant. It was given to him land immediately and a portion before his face at Arddachad Emain Macha. It was said that he had a good reputation among them. This is the one who is called 'king of Cind Berraide over the Ulaid,' i.e., king for half the day

They went to Crích Ross, towards Sciaig Aird na Con. The Ulaid were defeated in the battle of Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'My strength is this!' said Conall. 'I have given the king of the Ulaid a blow that would have killed him.' 'Not so,' said Cend Berraide, to his long-haired servant. They gave him a wound on the side and a blow on the head by Arddachad Emain Macha. They took him to the hospital. Conid was the one who was 'king of Cind Berraide over the Ulaid', that is, king for half a day

May it be good to the Crích Ross of Sciaig Aird na Con. The Ulaid were divided into two parts at Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'My word is this!' said Conall. 'The king of the Ulaid has not given me a portion of my territory.' 'Not so,' said Cend Berraide, to his servant. He gave him a share of land immediately and a portion before his face at Arddachad Emain Macha. May it be good to his kin. This is what is known as 'the king of Cind Berraide over the Ulaid,' i.e., the king for half the day

The men of Ross and the men of Sciaig Aird na Con were coming together. The Ulaid had been gathered in force to Áth Daire Dá Báeth. 'My share of this!' said Conall. 'The king of the Ulaid has given me the portion of the army which is mine.' 'Not yours,' said Cend Berraide, to his long-haired servant. He gave him a cloak and a garment for his head at Arddachad Emain Macha. The man's wife was in the hall. Conid was that 'king of Cind Berraide over the Ulaid', i.e., king over half the land
The knowledge of the truth was known from the beginning until the time of the king. We shall speak of it afterwards, concerning Ulster
They knew the truth of it from the beginning until the time of the king. We will speak of it afterwards, concerning Ulster
They knew the truth of it from the time before the king's death. We shall tell of it afterwards, concerning Ulster
They knew the truth from the beginning, before the king's death. We will tell it to you now, concerning Ulster

They were fighting together with their men against Conall, that is Fingen. It was the first time they had ever fought for the day or for the night in line without breaking from the galloping there, and they would not break from it again. 'Good,' said Fingen, 'the god of war will strike you from your head so that you may be killed by the spear. If you are not struck now, you will not find peace nor will you have anything else.' 'It is a strong fortress,' said Ulaid, 'that which you call your own.'

They brought him to where the Lia Fáil was with Conall, that is, Fingen. It was not fitting for the day nor for the king to be in line without a bid in that hall; thus, he came and every galloper without a bid came also. 'Good,' said Fingen, 'may the god of the stone come from your head and strike you dead under the chétóir. If they bring me to trial tomorrow, I will not be found guilty nor will they have anything against you.' 'It is a fair judgment,' said the Ulstermen, 'that he should be put to death for his deeds.'

Doberar took his daughter to Conall, that is Fingen. It was the custom of the day and the tradition of the tribe in line with the law in that territory to give him and every other man without exception. 'Good,' said Fingen, 'may the god bring the stone from your head so that you may be killed by a spear. If I am not slain now, I will not be found and you will be slain.' 'It is thus,' said Ulaid, 'that he who has been slain before shall be avenged.'

Bearar tra a liaig co Conall .i. Fingen. Iss éside nofhinnad don díaid nothéiged don tig in lín nobíd i ngalur 'sin tig ocus cech galar nobíd and. 'Maith,' or Fingen, 'dia taltar in chloch as do chind biat marb fo chétóir. Mani tucthar ass immorro, not-ícfaind ocus bid athis duit.' 'Is asso dún' ar Ulaid 'ind athis oldás a éc som

They struck her face and cast her into a heap of gold, which was the color of the skin of Conchobor and the color of gold. And they laid the blame upon Conall, saying that he had done it, i.e., that neither she had been harmed by him nor had he caused any injury to a man or taken a woman [nor had he cast her into the river] in secret nor had he fled

They struck her face and cast her into a heap of gold, which was the color of Conchobur's hair and the color of gold. And they declared the law upon Conall concerning every sin, that is, neither to be angry with him nor to strike him nor to take a woman from him [nor to steal from him] in secret nor to speak against him

They struck her face and cast her into a heap of gold, which was the custom of the color of Conchobar's skin and the color of gold. And they laid a curse upon Liaig against Conall so that he would not be in his mind, i.e., that he would not be able to fight for him nor to lead an army nor to take a wife [nor to eat bread] with his own hand nor to speak

They struck her face and wounded her with a golden spear, which was the color of the shield of Conchobor and the color of gold. And they set the laig on Conall so that he should not be in peace, i.e., that he should not have his quarrel settled for him nor be healed from injury nor be married to women [nor have food] in plenty nor go out

Roboi dano isin chuntabairt sin céin robo beó, i.e., secht mbliadna ocus nírbo engnamaid, ach a airisium inna shuidi nammá, i.e., naco cúala Críst do chrochad do Iudaidib. Tánic and side crith mór forsna dúli ocus rochrithnaig nem ocus talam la mét in gníma darónad and, i.e., Ísu Críst mac Dé bí do chrochad cen chinaid. 'Cráet so?' ar Conall fria drúid. 'Cia olc mór dogníther isind lathiu-sa indiú?' 'Is fir ón ém,' ar in drúi. 'Is mór in gním sin,' ar Conall. 'In fer sin dano,' ar in drúi, 'i n-óenaidchi rogein ocus rogenisiu, i.e., i n-ocht calde Enair cen cop inund bliadain

Roboi dano isin chuntabairt sin céin robo beó, i.e., secht mbliadna ocus nírbo engnamaid, ach a airisium inna shuidi nammá, i.e., naco cúala Críst do chrochad do Iudaidib. Tánic and side crith mór forsna dúli ocus rochrithnaig nem ocus talam la mét in gníma darónad and, i.e., Ísu Críst mac Dé bí do chrochad cen chinaid. 'Cráet so?' ar Conall fria drúid. 'Cia olc mór dogníther isind lathiu-sa indiú?' 'Is fir ón ém,' ar in drúi. 'Is mór in gním sin,' ar Conall. 'In fer sin dano,' ar in drúi, 'i n-óenaidchi rogein ocus rogenisiu, i.e., i n-ocht calde Enair cen cop inund bliadain

Roboi dano isin chuntabairt sin céin robo beó, i.e., secht mbliadna ocus nírbo engnamaid, ach a airisium inna shuidi nammá, i.e., naco cúala Críst do chrochad do Iudaidib. Tánic and side crith mór forsna dúli ocus rochrithnaig nem ocus talam la mét in gníma darónad and, i.e., Ísu Críst mac Dé bí do chrochad cen chinaid. 'Cráet so?' ar Conall fria drúid. 'Cia olc mór dogníther isind lathiu-sa indiú?' 'Is fir ón ém,' ar in drúi. 'Is mór in gním sin,' ar Conall. 'In fer sin dano,' ar in drúi, 'i n-óenaidchi rogein ocus rogenis-siu, i.e., i n-ocht calde Enair cen cop inund bliadain

Roboi dano in that council, a certain man was alive, namely seven years and not engendered, but born from the seed of women, namely not hearing Christ's preaching to the Jews. He made a great law before the people, and he wrote it down in a book and sealed it with wax in the manner of the Druids. Namely, Jesus Christ, son of God, was born without sin. 'What is this?' said Conall to the Druid. 'What great evil has been done in this generation?' 'It is from the east,' said the Druid. 'That is a great law,' said Conall. 'This man,' said the Druid, 'came from the east and came to them, namely eight men of Enair without a head for three years
And this is the recitation of Conall. And it is this that the man recited to God in Hérin before the time of the creed, namely, Morand the other man
And this is the recitation of Conall. And it is this that the man recited to God in Hérin before the time of the creed, namely, Morand the other man
And this is the death of Conall. And it is that he was the first man to be killed for God in Ireland before the time of the creed, namely Morand the other man
And this is the recitation of Conall. And it is this that the man recited to God in Hérin before the time of the creation, namely, Morand the other man

And then Conall said: 'I would rather die in the battle of my own choice than be captured by the Jews of the tribe of Christ's cross.' Then they were drawn and a red flame was kindled, and Mesgegra was struck down from his head, and Concubur was wounded with a spear. The Gaels then said that Concubur would not live to see the day when he would be given peace in the land of the Irish, for he had been slain by the hand of Christ. And it was there that Conall's soul was carried to the company of Christ against his will, along with the fire of his own soul, for Christ took Conall's soul from him. Finid

And then Conall said: 'I would rather die in the battle of my own choice than be captured by the Jews of the tribe of Christ's cross.' Then they were drawn and a red flame was kindled before Mesgegra from his head, and Concubur was struck down as a forerunner. The Gaels then declared that Concubur would not be allowed to live in Ireland, for he had caused great harm to the people of Christ, and it was said that Christ would strike him with death. Finid

And then Conall said: 'I will not allow any man to live in the life of my kin who would fight against the Jews in the time of Christ's crucifixion.' Then they were drawn and a red flame came forth from the head of Mesgegra, and Concubur was struck down by it. The men of Gaeidhil then said that Concubur had been struck with a deadly wound, which would be his death in blood from his head. And indeed, then Conall's soul was carried to the company of Christ along with the light of his soul, for Christ took Conall's soul with him to the land of the dead. Finid

And after that Conall said: 'I will give the men in my company to battle against the Jews who have crossed with Christ's name, if I may be able to fight against them.' Then they were seized and dragged forth by the assembly of the clergy and the bishops of Mesgeagra from their midst and Concubur the scribe. The sons of the Gaedhil and Concubur the scribe would have brought a great number of men to the assistance of the Irish, if it had been possible for them to fight with him. And in that place Conall's soul was taken to the company of Christ against his will, because of the pride of his soul. Finid

It was the custom of the men of the province to go to the battle of Me[i]sgegra, and they would set out from the province for the army. The people of Cet did that thing. They brought Ethaid into the battle by force against his will and gave him over to them, so that Cet might be in the forefront of the battle with Messgegra, to take the spoil from them. Every battle and every raid was forbidden to the Connacht men concerning Ulster, but Cet took the battle and the plundering of the people of Ulster for the sake of the third part of the spoils of the Ulstermen for their death

It is the custom of the people to give a portion of their food to the poor, and it was thus that Cet gave alms to the poor. Ethaid took from the portion of the food which was given to him, and he gave it to Cet who was in need of sustenance for Messgegra, whom he had brought up from childhood. Every battle and every raid which the Connacht men made against Ulster, Cet took a share of the plunder, and he distributed it among the poor of Ulster as a tribute to their king

Intan bátar na ónmite 'co cluchiu do inchind Me[i]sgegra, issed atbert ind ónmit fri araile. Rocluinedar Cet aní sin. Ethaid side in n-inchind al-láim indala n-ái ocus berid leiss, ó rofitir Cet robói i tarngere do Messgegra a dígail iarna écaib. Cach cath ocus cach irga[l] nobíd do Chonnachtaib fri Ulto dobered Cet in n-inchind inna chriss dús in tetarthad écht n-amra d’ Ultaib do marbad di

It is not the case that the whole of the people was gathered together to the assembly of the Messengers, but a part of them came to the assembly on account of their own desire. The matter of that was discussed. Ethaid went into the assembly in the morning and took with him his weapons, and he said to them, 'Let me go, for Cet who was in the army of the Messengers was killed yesterday.' Every battle and every war which was not agreed upon by the Connacht men against Ulster, Cet would be in the assembly of those who were under the king's command, taking the third part of the plunder from the Ulstermen for their dead

Loích was born to Mumab, namely Mac Connaid and Marrcán and Óengus. It is said: Not one of them was in the company of the woman of Hossairge, without Mac Connaid, without Marrcán, without Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin was a man of great strength; he would throw the other men's weapons from their hands. Then came to Óengus Huí Máil and it was a great sorrow that came upon them. It is said: Huí Máil had three hundred men in his host; but Óengus had only three score of them. As they were about to fight, they said: 'It is a shame for me, Huí Máil, and a grief for the harvest of grain; welcome be Huí Máil to his kin and it is fitting every man to his portion

Loích was born to Mumab, that is Mac Connaid and Marrcán and Óengus. It is said: Not one of them was in the company of the woman of Hossairge, without Mac Connaid, without Marrcán, without Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin was the most handsome man among them; the others were not as handsome as he. Then came to Óengus Huí Máil and it was a great sorrow for him that they came. It is said: Huí Máil had three hundred men in his following; but Óengus had only three hundred men from them. As they went forth, they said: 'It is my will, Huí Máil, and my desire with the joy of grain; welcome to you, Huí Máil, for your kin and for every good thing for your people

Loích was the son of Mumab, namely Mac Connaid and Marccán and Óengus. It is said: Not one of them was in the company of the wife of Ossairge, without Mac Connaid, without Marccán, without Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin was the most handsome man among them; the others were not even comparable to him in beauty. Afterwards, they went to Óengus Huí Máil and it was agreed that they would pay him tribute. It is said: Huí Máil had three hundred men under his command; but Óengus had only three hundred men. They said afterwards: 'It is a shame for me, Huí Máil, and a loss of the harvest of grain; welcome to you, Huí Máil, in your kinship and it is fitting every gift for your protection

Loích was the father of Mumu, namely Mac Connaid and Marccán and Óengus. It is said that neither of them was born from the womb of Hossairge, without Mac Connaid, without Marccán, without Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin was the most numerous man among them; the rest of the clans were not equal to him in numbers. Afterwards, a meeting was held with Óengus Huí Máil, and it was agreed that his meeting should be held first. It is said that Huí Máil had three hundred men under him; but Óengus had only three noble men from them. As they made their agreement: 'It is my will, Huí Máil, and the will of the grain's joy; welcome to you, Huí Máil, for your kinship and every right of your territory

The king of the men of Máel will not be able to do so. The son of Óengus took his wife. She went to the place where her husband was, and she found her mother-in-law in the glen. Her mother-in-law said to her husband: 'Good,' said the woman, 'my assembly is in the night. But there are three men of the household who are not in the house, and they will not be able to come to you in the night, but they will be able to come to your good. Bring me all my wealth for that journey, and bring with it that it is she who is in the house and she is in the house, and she will be in the house until the morning.'

The men of the king of the race of Máel will not be there tomorrow. The son of Óengus took his wife. She went to that place to fight for her father's honor and her mother's glory in the battle. Her father was slain by the enemy before him, and her brothers were slain before him. 'Good,' said the woman, 'my two sons were killed at night. But there are three warriors of the household left, and they will not be able to fight against them in the battle at night, but they will be able to fight for their good. You shall have all my wealth for that victory, and you shall say it is this that was done, and she was in the house and she died in the house, and she was buried in the house.'

The king of the race of Máel will not be able to do so. The son of Óengus took his wife. She went to her father's house to bring her mother a cow from Galway. Her father gave her in marriage to a man of good character. 'Good,' said the woman, 'my two sons were with me last night. But three young men came to me last night and did not give me any money for it, but they gave me good things. Bring me all my silver for that sinning, and bring also what is true that she was in it and was in her own house, and let her be in the house with her husband, and let her be in the house with her husband, and let her be in the house with her husband, and let her be in the house with her husband, and let her be in the house with her husband, and let her be in the house with her husband

The daughter of the king of the Ui Mail went forth. She made Oengus her lover. She went to meet him for a fight against her father and her mother's kinsmen in Galway. Her father, who was old, fell before him by the hand of his son. 'Good,' said the woman, 'my assembly is with me tonight. But there are three hundred men of war and they will not be able to pass through the night, but they will be able to pass through the good ones among them. You shall have all my wealth for this victory, and you shall say that it was I who did it and that she was in her house and he was in the house, and she fell by a spear.'

It is true from the Tiagait that they were not immune to new weapons. Congairet said fair. 'Innafhail tall, O Engus?' 'Cosmail my life,' said Oengus, 'and not to kill for six. We will take their heads.' 'My head, indeed,' said the woman. With a sudden blow I struck the head of the woman and gave her a wound in the side and a spear thrust through the body. 'There was food in me,' said she, 'in the fight with you. My daughter and for the girl herself were killed.' And then arose a cry from the people at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made a covenant between them on lines

It is true from the Tiagait that they were not immune to new weapons. Congairet said fair. 'Innafhail tall, O Engus?' 'Cosmail my life,' said Oengus, 'and not to kill for six. We will take their heads.' 'My head, indeed,' said the woman. With a clean blade I cut off the heads of the women and gave them to him, and he took a fine head and went on his way. 'There was food in my house,' said she, 'in the fight that was here. My daughter and for the girl herself were killed.' And then they found a cow's hide in the place at that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made a covenant with each other by lines

It is true from the time when they were not yet born. Congairet fair. 'Is this a fair death, O Oengus?' 'It is my own will,' said Oengus, 'and not to kill for six. Let them be buried in the ground.' 'My son,' said the woman, 'by the head of my father I swear, I will not let you go until I have killed the women and given their heads to you and carried their bodies away.' 'It was food that I had,' said she, 'in this house. My daughter and for the girl herself were slain.' And then they found a cow in the field on that day. Then Oengus and Aithechda made a truce between them

It is true from the Tiagait that when they were immune to new poisons. Congairet said fairly. 'Innafhail tall, O Engus?' 'Cosmail my life,' said Oengus, 'and not to kill for six. No one will be killed by them.' 'My son,' said the old man. With a clean blade I cut off the heads of the women and gave each of them their own head and they went forth in sorrow. 'There was food,' said she, 'in my house. My daughter and the girl herself were slain.' And thus they found the corpse on that day when they were there. Then afterwards Oengus and Aithechda made a pact between them

The woman said to Reimpi in the presence of Colman, and she gave him this verse:— 'To Colman the pilgrim, have you heard the news of the nimble? six to you is your fair-haired one, the noble youth.' 'I am a pilgrim,' said he, 'and I will not be ashamed; every one [who] says it is false, not the noble youth.' 'It is my youth,' said she, 'my fair-haired one.' 'Take that as a gift,' said Colman, 'and let it be given to Aena

The woman said to Reimpi in the presence of Colman, and she gave him this verse:— 'To Colman the pilgrim, have you heard the news of the nimble? six to you is your noble lineage. the fair maiden.' 'I am a pilgrim,' said he, 'and I will not be ashamed; every one [who] says it is false. not from the noble lineage.' 'It is my noble lineage,' said she, 'my own son.' 'That is a falsehood,' said Colman, 'and that is for Aena

The woman spoke to Reimpi concerning Colmán, and she said the verse:— 'To Colmán the pilgrim, have you heard the news of the clouds? You are the one who has the true knowledge.' 'I am a pilgrim,' said he, 'and I will be a sinner; every word that is spoken, it is not fitting for a Sunday.' 'It is my Sunday,' said she, 'my son's.' 'That sin you have committed,' said Colmán, 'will be forgiven for Aena

The woman spoke to Reimpi in the presence of Colman, and she recited this verse:—'To Colman the warrior, have you not heard the cry of the heavens? It is your true name that is known to none but the beloved.' 'I am the warrior, and I chase the beautiful; every one [who] sings of me, does not know my true name.' 'My true name,' she said, 'is my little son.' 'Take that name then,' said Colman, 'and let it be known by Aena

It was true. They killed a youth from the people of Cluana Ech Aena, who had come out of his farm. The youth from Aena took hold of the hundred cows from the youth in the field. The youth said that to Colman, who had been given it. 'Take the portion for Aena,' said Colman

It was true. They killed a youth from the people of Cluana Ech Aena, who had come out of his farm. The youth from Aena took hold of the hundred cows from the youth in the field. The youth said that to Colmán, who had been given it. 'Take the portion for Aena,' said Colmán

It was true. They killed a youth from the people of Cluana Ech Aena, who had come out of his farm. The youth from Aena took a cow from the hundred cows of the youth in the field. The youth said that to Colman, who was present. 'Take the ransom for Aena,' said Colman

It was true, the son. He killed a youth from the people of Cluana Ech Aena who had come out of his town. The youth from Aena took from him the hundred cows that were in his cowshed. Then the youth came to Colman for help. 'Take the plunder from Aena,' said Colman

The bard recited a poem to Aena, and took the verse, that is: 'A man of the plain came before Aena, and he took the verse: 'O son of Laígse, great was your strength in the head of the hundred cows; great was your going to the bull in the fullness of the sacred bull.' 'It is a bull tomorrow,' said Aena: 'they do not seek a fortress but a cow.' Thus spoke that man in accordance with the meaning between Aena and Colmán

The bard recited a poem to Aena, and took up the verse: 'The son of Laígse was great in the head of the hundred cows; the great one to go to the bull in the fair of the cattle.' 'It is a bull,' said Aena: 'they do not seek strength but a heifer.' Then they both went together from Aena and Colmán

The bard recited a poem to Aena, and took the verse: 'The son of Laígse was great in the head of the hundred cows; the great one to go to the heifer in the fold of the cowherd.' 'It is a heifer,' said Aena: 'they do not seek a bull but a heifer.' Thus spoke that man between Aena and Colmán

The poet recited a verse to Aena, and took the stanza: 'The son of Laígse was great in his head over the first cow; the great one would go to the milk-pail of the milch-cow.' 'It is full now,' said Aena: 'they do not seek strength but the calf.' Thus was that saying accepted between Aena and Colmán

It was there that Óengus was killed by the men of Aithechdai, and it was for his own men that he was slain. (It was not Dubchrón who killed Óengus at that time.) Then a man from the east came to him with a grey spear, and struck him in the eye and in the face, and the people of Aithechda were gathered around him (i.e., in the house of Óengus) until three men came to slay him. They cut off his head, and they took his red hair and his mantle from his head. Dubchrón was taken for Dubglais, i.e., for his own taking. 'Treason, O Dubchrón,' said he. 'Not so,' said Dubchrón. 'What of Óengus?' 'He is in the cotlud; sit, sit, and do not be afraid. Treason and treachery in this house.' 'I will not take his cotlud unless it be given to me by right. Take the mantle from him,' said he. He took it. 'Truth, O Óengus,' said he. And he said: 'Deithbir for your taking what is white of the condránic for faeburdán; imma·rulaid ilar lám in cenn fil for Óengus

It was there that Óengus was in the house of Aithechdai, and it was for men to strike him with his death. (It was not Dubchrón who was a servant of Óengus at that time.) Then a man came from the east with a grey spear, and he struck my eye and my face and the people of Athechda, so that they would be in the place (.i. in the house of Óengus) until three men would strike them with their weapons. Then he cut off his head, and it was given to him for his redness and for his mantle over his head. Dubchrón took up the spear, .i. his own spear. 'Fighting, O Dubchrón,' said he. 'Not so,' said Dubchrón. 'What of Óengus?' 'He is in the cotlud; sit, sit, on what you do not know. Fighting and fighting this house.' 'I will not strike him unless it be with a blow from the air. Take the mantle from his face,' said he. He took it. 'Truth, O Óengus,' said he. And he said: 'Deithbir to him who strikes, whatever is white in the condition of the face; imma·rulaid ilar lám in cenn fil for Óengus

There was, however, a man named Oengus who was of the tribe of Aithechdai, and he was killed by men from his own side. (It was not Dubcrón the servant of Oengus at that time.) Then a man from the east came to them with grey hair, old eyes, and old hands, and he brought the clan of Athechda to the place where they would be slain (.i. to the place of Oengus), so that three men were killed in one night. They afterwards cut off his head, and they took his red hair and his mantle from his head. Dubcrón was then struck by Dubglais .i. by his own hand. 'Flee, Dubcrón,' said he. 'Not I,' said Dubcrón. 'Where is Oengus?' 'He is in the cotlud; sit, sit, on what you do not know. Flee and flee to that house.' 'I will not flee from him unless he be a friend. Take the mantle from his body,' said he. He took it. 'True, Oengus,' said he. And he said: 'The death of the man who was killed by the hand of the woman; may the woman be cursed for her deed; may she be struck on the head with the hand of Oengus

They said that, indeed, Óengus was in the ambush of the people of Aithechdai and he was struck with a spear through his body. (It was not Dubchrón who killed Óengus at that time.) Then a man from the household of the king of Aithechda came forward, holding a red spear in his hand, and the people of Aithechda came after him to fight alongside them (i.e., into the place of Óengus) so that three men would be slain together. They afterwards severed his head and carried it off for his blood and for his garment over his head. Dubchrón was then killed by Dubglais, i.e., by his own hand. 'Throwing, Dubchrón,' said he. 'Not at all,' said Dubchrón. 'What is Óengus?' 'He is in the fortress; sit, sit, on that which does not disturb you. Throwing and throwing this thing.' 'I will not throw his fortress unless it be with a man who would carry it off. Take the garment from him,' said he. He took it. 'Truth, Óengus,' said he. And he said: 'Deibhid to his people what is white according to the condition of the fight; indeed, they have thrown the head of Óengus before them
